slidetranscripts.slidetranscript: Hello everyone! Welcome to the lecture on understanding statistical inferences. This lecture is designed by Dr. Candace Chou and narrated by Dr. Karen Kozen-Lien.

By the end of the lecture, you will understand:

• Purpose and nature of inferential statistics

• Level of significance

• Hypothesis Testing

• Statistical and practical significance

• Specific Inferential Tests using

§ t-Test

§ Analysis of Variance

§ Chi-square

• Criteria for evaluating inferential statistics

We know some of you may frown upon hearing the word “statistics.” Remember this lecture is about ”understanding” how inferential statistics can help us make sense of educational research studies, not how to carry out your own research with statistical analysis. We will try to make it as plain as possible with lots of examples.

So what are inferential statistics? They are mathematical procedures that use descriptive statistics to make inferences about characteristics of a population.

o They are used to determine what is likely to be true.

o They can be used to investigate the level of uncertainty in quantitative studies.

o The degree of confidence depends on the error in sampling and measurement.

For example, if we know a small sample of sixth-graders will pass an accountability test, how certain can we be that all sixth-graders will pass it? We can use inferential statistics to infer the likely outcomes but the degree of confidence depends on the amount of error in sampling and measurement.

Sampling is used as a procedure for studying a portion of a larger population.

Samples and sampling error

-Samples are used to provide descriptives that represent a population.

• e.g., Data from 100 randomly-selected seventh graders is used to make inferences about 1000 seventh graders.

-There is a certain degree of error in sampling. We should take the error into account in making the inference to the population. Each time you take a random sample, the results will be slightly different. If you take a second or third sample of 100 students, which one can you be most certain to provide the most accurate estimate of the whole population? The answer is we don’t know because we do not have the measure of the entire population.

Supposed that we can measure the entire population, there will be measurement error too.

Measurement error refers to the difference between the “true” score and the observed score. Taking measurement in attitude, achievement, and motivation for example, each time you measure something, the results will be slightly different.

For example, data collected from a student on two separate occasions, one early in the morning and one late in the day, will be slightly different pending on the reliability of the measurement. Therefore, we need to take measurement error, as well as sampling error, into consideration.

Usually in quantitative research, we identify a problem and then formulate hypotheses.

• Inferential statistics are based on a set of procedures developed by Ronald Fisher in the 1920’s.

• The procedures use a method of deductive logic.

• The procedure for making a decision about whether or not it is likely there is a difference between two groups begins with the null hypothesis.

The null hypothesis is

• A statement that there are no differences between groups or no relationships between variables

• We reject the null when there is a difference or relationship.

• We fail to reject the null when there isn’t a difference or relationship.

A hypothesis is stated a bit differently in a correlational than in an experimental study, but a relationship is implied. For example…

Correlational: There will be a significant relationship between peer group acceptance and attitude toward school.

Experimental: There will be no significant differences between Treatment Group A and Treatment Group B with respect to achievement.

Level of significance

• Inferential statistics are used to indicate the probability of being wrong in rejecting the null.

• The probability is called the level of significance or alpha (a) which is indicated with the small italic letter p (probability) and is reported as p = x or p < x (i.e., the level of significance is .05 or less than .05)

• The value of p indicates how often the results would be obtained just due to chance.

• If the level of significance is .05, then we are willing to accept a 5% chance that we are wrong in rejecting the null.

• If p = 0.2, there is a 20% probably that the difference is due to a chance variation, that is, error in sampling and measurement. That is too great a chance to accept in research.

• If the level of significance is .001, there is only 1 chance out of 1,000 that the difference obtained is due to chance. This would be a more probable result than a p value of .01 (1 chance out of 100).

• Usually for the outcomes to be “statistically significant” different, the level of significance should be .05% or less.

• The level of significance helps us make a statistical decision related to the null hypothesis but it does not tell us anything about why there was a difference. When the null hypothesis is rejected, we examine the design of the study to see whether there are extraneous variables that may explain the results.

• If the null hypothesis is not rejected, we are tempted to conclude that there is, in reality, no difference or no relationship. In a well-designed study, failure to reject the null hypothesis is just as important, scientifically, as rejecting it.

There are two types of error in hypothesis testing.

Type I error is thinking there is a difference when there is not. In other words, researchers make a decision to reject the null hypothesis when it is, in fact, true (no difference in the population), the researcher has made what is called a type I error.

Type II error is thinking there is not a difference when there is.

There are many factors affecting the significant level, including the difference between groups, sample size, and variance within groups.

Some people argue that making a dichotomous yes/no decision based on an arbitrary level of significance is fundamentally flawed. It is important to understand the limitation of null hypothesis testing although it’s not going away anytime soon.

There are three other ways to supplement inferential significance testing: descriptive statistics, confidence intervals, and effect size.

We have learned in previous lectures that simple descriptive statistics are absolutely essential to understand a statistically significant result. Scatterplot and graphs are also very helpful in data analysis. Here is a quick review of how descriptive statistics are reported. Pause the video to review them.

Confidence interval (CI)

• It provides a range of values in which the “true” population value probably lies.

• It is calculated with the same data used for significance tests, but there is no p value.

• Take the sample data, the researcher calculates a measure of variability called the standard error of the mean (SEx). This value is then used to create score-based intervals around the sample mean that correspond to the probability of obtaining a population value in that interval.

For example, if a sample mean is 60, a researcher might have a 95% confidence interval of 48-72. This means that there is a 95% chance that the population or “true” mean is somewhere in this interval between 48 and 72. By presenting confidence intervals, researchers use variability in reporting results. This gives you a sense of how likely the population values differ.

Researchers use the word “significant” in two ways. In one sense, it refers to a statistical inference. When we say that something is statistical significant, we are saying that there is a difference in two groups. To assess statistical significance, we examine the test’s p-value. If the p-value is less than .05 or .01, you can declare the difference to be statistically significant and reject the test’s null hypothesis.

For example, suppose you want to determine if a new learning strategy has impact on the test scores of students in experimental and control groups. The average score of students in the experimental group is 92 out of 100. The average score in students in the control group is 90. Suppose that the p-value is less than .05 (p<.05), this is statistical significant, meaning the new learning strategy does make a difference in student test scores. However, in practice, the difference between 92 and 90 might not be that great. Converting the score to a letter grade, both are at the range of A-.

Practical significance implies importance or meaningfulness of the practical value of the correlation. This involves looking at the effect size to determine the practical significance. We will discuss the concept of effect size in the next slide.

Effect size provides a way of quantifying the strength of the relationship or the degree of difference. In another words, it is a way of quantifying the magnitude of an observed difference. It is the difference between means as a function of the variance. A simple formula, called Cohen’s d, is often used with two groups, where the mean of experimental group is subtracted by the mean of control group and then divided by the standard deviation of the control group. We then get a standard score.

For example, we might get an Effect Size of .50, that’s half of the standard deviations above the mean. This is a moderate difference between the two groups. Effect size is interpreted as small, moderate, or large. When the effect size equals to or is small than .25, it is regarded as “small” significant. The meaning of the effect size is ultimately a matter of professional judgment.

In this example, a study on how often teachers use different types of assignments to work with gifted students and regular students, the effect size for “assign advanced level reading” is 0.622 which means there is an important difference between the two groups. Teachers are reported to have a higher frequency in using “advance level readings” for gifted students. The mean for Gifted student group is 2.83, higher than the mean of the regular student group of 2.03. The frequency is reported weekly.

The next classroom practice item on the table, “use self-instructional kit”, the effect size is .098 which is a small effect size indicating there’s not much difference between the two groups.

Effect size gives you an indication of how much difference is there between the two groups.

There are many different inferential statistical procedures.

• Which one is appropriate depends on the research design and type of variables.

• Parametric methods are based on the assumption the data are normally distributed, variances are equal, and the measures are at least interval level.

• If these assumptions cannot be met, nonparametric statistics can be used, including t-test, ANOVA, and Chi-Square.

• t – test is mainly used for interval or ration data.

• Most often used to test if two group means are the same.

• Can be used to test if a correlation coefficient is different from zero (i.e., no correlation).

• Can be used to compare a mean to a set value.

• Researchers report t-values for each test, with their corresponding p values and degrees of freedom (degree of freedom usually is equal to the sample size minus 1).

• T – test comes in two forms

• Independent-samples t-test is used in designs where they are different individuals in each group, e.g., control vs. experimental groups.

• Dependent-samples t-test is used in designs where the participants are paired or matched in some way.

o e.g., Used to compare two means from a pretest and posttest taken by the same group of individuals

To report the results of a t-test, the following information is included:

• The level of significant (alpha level) is expressed as p < .05.

• It means (roughly) that there is less than 5 instances in 100 that these results occurred by chance or error.

• P values may also be reported as p < .01 or p < .001

Examples: Teachers who reported that their current teaching assignment was special education (n=50) were compared to teachers who reported that their current teaching assignment was general education (n=275). Only one of the measure’s p values fell below .05; individual achievement tests (t = 2.24, df = 299, p= .026).

Simple Analysis of Variance (or ANOVA)

• It usually requires interval or ratio data.

• It is an extension of the t-test which allows comparison of more than two group means

• Also called one-way ANOVA.

• e.g., Researcher compares means on a history exam of three groups of students—high, middle, low SES.

Here’s a graphic representation of Simple Analysis of Variance (ANOVA)

The results are reported as an F statistic, with the corresponding p value and the degrees of freedom

A significant result indicates that the mean of at least one of the groups is significantly different.

Chi-square test of independence

• Chi-square is the most common nonparametric test.

• It is used to determine if there is a relationship between two nominal variables.

• The result is often reported as a contingency coefficient based on information in a contingency table.

Here’s one example of how Chi-Square is reported. Here we compare binge drinking between females and males. The results show a significant difference between female and male college students in binge drinking.

There are several criteria for evaluating inferential studies:

• Descriptive statistics are needed to evaluate the results.

• Results refer to statistical, not practical, significance.

• Statistical significance is determined in part by sample size.

• The level of significance should be interpreted correctly.

• Inferential statistics do not indicate external or internal validity.

• Results depend on the number of intervention replications.

• The appropriate test should be used.

• Be wary of tests with small sample sizes or with scads of tests in a single study.

In this video, we have learned different ways to understand statistical inferences data via the following topics:

• Purpose and Nature of Inferential Statistics

• Level of significance

• Hypothesis Testing

• Statistical and practical significance

• Specific Inferential Tests using

- t-Test

- Analysis of Variance

- Chi-square

• Criteria for evaluating inferential statistics
